dc:title: A general model to account for enzyme variation in natural populations. III. Multiple alleles
dc:creator: Gillespie J.
dc:description: The recent findings of increased numbers of alleles at enzyme loci suggests that models of balancing selection must use biologically motivated constraints of the fitnesses if stable, multiple-allele equilibria are to be explained. The constraints introduced in Gillespie (1976) that enzyme activity is an additive trait across alleles and that fitness is a concave function of enzyme activity, is shown in this paper to allow the maintainance of an arbitrarily large number of alleles in a randomly fluctuating environment. The condition for polymorphism for n alleles requires, roughly, that the mean difference in activity between neighboring homozygous genotypes is less than twice the variance in activity divided by the square of the number of alleles.
